byline.contributor: Robert Pear and Margot Sanger-Katz reported from Washington, and Reed Abelson from New York. Sabrina Tavernise, Abby Goodnough and Jonathan Weisman contributed reporting from Washington, and Nicholas Confessore from New York.
byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, MARGOT SANGER-KATZ and REED ABELSON

abstract: Affordable Care Act, reaffirmed by Supreme Court, has transformed health care system in nation, giving treatment and coverage to millions of uninsured people, but it still faces strong political headwinds in many places and could still be volatile issue in 2016 elections; many questions about law's effects were not resolved by ruling, including whether it is making health care affordable for most people.
lead_paragraph: They appear to have drawn substantial numbers of younger, healthier people into the new insurance markets, stabilizing premiums, even for those who pay the full cost.

headline.main: Insurance Subsidies Remain, but So Do Health Law Questions
headline.print_headline: If Law ‘Is Here to Stay,’ So Are Doubts About It

snippet: They appear to have drawn substantial numbers of younger, healthier people into the new insurance markets, stabilizing premiums, even for those who pay the full cost.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
